words.english: The fundamental German word order rule
words.example: Ich gehe heute ins Kino. Heute gehe ich ins Kino.
words.example_translation: I go to the cinema today. Today I go to the cinema.
words.rule: The conjugated verb is always in second position in main clauses
words.notes: This is called the V2 rule - most important German syntax rule

words.english: Standard word order when subject comes first
words.example: Der Mann kauft ein Auto.
words.example_translation: The man buys a car.
words.rule: When subject is in position 1, order is like English
words.notes: This feels natural for English speakers

words.english: Subject and verb switch when adverb comes first
words.example: Morgen fahre ich nach Berlin.
words.example_translation: Tomorrow I drive to Berlin.
words.rule: When anything other than subject is first, verb stays second
words.notes: Subject moves after verb to keep verb in position 2

words.english: Question word order follows same rule
words.example: Wann fährst du nach Berlin?
words.example_translation: When do you drive to Berlin?
words.rule: Question word + verb + subject + rest
words.notes: W-questions follow normal V2 pattern

words.example: Ich verstehe nicht. Er kommt nicht.
words.example_translation: I don't understand. He's not coming.
words.rule: 'Nicht' often goes at the end of the sentence
words.notes: Safest position for beginners

words.example: Ich gehe nicht ins Kino. Er ist nicht alt.
words.example_translation: I'm not going to the cinema. He is not old.
words.rule: 'Nicht' comes before what it negates (prepositional phrases, adjectives)
words.notes: More precise negation

words.example: Ich stehe nicht auf. Er ruft nicht an.
words.example_translation: I don't get up. He doesn't call.
words.rule: 'Nicht' comes before the separable prefix
words.notes: Nicht goes between verb parts

words.example: Das ist nicht mein Auto. / Ich habe kein Auto.
words.example_translation: That's not my car. / I don't have a car.
words.rule: Nicht negates definite things, kein negates indefinite things
words.notes: Review of Week 3 concept with word order

words.example: Ich fahre morgen mit dem Auto nach Berlin.
words.example_translation: I drive tomorrow by car to Berlin.
words.rule: When combining adverbs: Time - Manner - Place
words.notes: TMP = easy way to remember the order

words.example: heute, morgen, um 8 Uhr, am Montag
words.example_translation: today, tomorrow, at 8 o'clock, on Monday
words.rule: Time information comes first in TMP order
words.pattern: [Time expression] comes before manner and place
words.notes: Answer to 'when?' comes first

words.example: schnell, mit dem Auto, zu Fuß, allein
words.example_translation: quickly, by car, on foot, alone
words.rule: Manner information comes second in TMP order
words.pattern: [Manner expression] comes after time, before place
words.notes: Answer to 'how?' comes second

words.example: nach Hause, in die Schule, hier, dort
words.example_translation: home, to school, here, there
words.rule: Place information comes last in TMP order
words.pattern: [Place expression] comes after time and manner
words.notes: Answer to 'where?' comes last

words.example: Ich trinke Kaffee und esse Kuchen.
words.example_translation: I drink coffee and eat cake.
words.rule: 'Und' connects words, phrases, or clauses without changing word order
words.notes: Most basic conjunction, no word order change

words.example: Trinkst du Kaffee oder Tee?
words.example_translation: Do you drink coffee or tea?
words.rule: 'Oder' shows alternatives without changing word order
words.notes: Used for choices and alternatives

words.example: Ich bin müde, aber ich arbeite weiter.
words.example_translation: I am tired, but I continue working.
words.rule: 'Aber' shows contrast without changing word order
words.notes: Often with comma before 'aber'

words.example: Ich bleibe zu Hause, denn ich bin krank.
words.example_translation: I stay home, for I am sick.
words.rule: 'Denn' gives reasons without changing word order
words.notes: More formal than 'weil', no word order change

words.english: Explaining reasons with changed word order
words.example: Ich bleibe zu Hause, weil ich krank bin.
words.example_translation: I stay home because I am sick.
words.rule: After 'weil', the conjugated verb goes to the end
words.notes: This is different from coordinating conjunctions!

words.english: Reporting what someone said or thought
words.example: Ich denke, dass er heute kommt.
words.example_translation: I think that he comes today.
words.rule: After 'dass', the conjugated verb goes to the end
words.notes: Used after verbs like denken, sagen, glauben

words.example: Ich gehe nicht mit, weil ich keine Zeit habe.
words.example_translation: I'm not coming along because I don't have time.
words.rule: Always use comma before subordinating conjunctions
words.notes: Comma is mandatory in German

words.example: Weil ich krank bin, bleibe ich zu Hause.
words.example_translation: Because I am sick, I stay home.
words.rule: If subordinate clause is first, main clause verb comes right after comma
words.notes: Subordinate clause counts as position 1, so verb is position 2

words.example: Wenn es regnet, bleibe ich zu Hause.
words.example_translation: If/When it rains, I stay home.
words.rule: 'Wenn' sends verb to end, used for conditions or repeated time
words.notes: Can mean 'if' or 'when' depending on context

words.example: Ich weiß nicht, ob er kommt.
words.example_translation: I don't know whether/if he's coming.
words.rule: 'Ob' is used for indirect questions, verb goes to end
words.notes: Used instead of direct yes/no questions

words.english: When something happened once in the past
words.example: Als ich klein war, spielte ich gern.
words.example_translation: When I was small, I liked to play.
words.rule: 'Als' for single past events, verb goes to end
words.notes: Different from 'wenn' - 'als' is for past, single events

words.example: sagen, denken, glauben, wissen, hoffen
words.example_translation: to say, think, believe, know, hope
words.rule: These verbs often introduce subordinate clauses with 'dass'
words.notes: Learn these verbs that take subordinate clauses

words.english: Using coordinating and subordinating conjunctions together
words.example: Ich gehe einkaufen, und dann koche ich, weil wir Hunger haben.
words.example_translation: I go shopping, and then I cook because we are hungry.
words.rule: Can combine different types of conjunctions in complex sentences
words.notes: Watch word order in each clause type

words.english: Common mistakes with German word order
words.example: Wrong: Ich weil krank bin bleibe zu Hause. Right: Ich bleibe zu Hause, weil ich krank bin.
words.example_translation: I stay home because I am sick.
words.rule: Subordinating conjunctions change word order, coordinating don't
words.notes: This is the most common word order mistake

words.example: Heute gehe ich mit meiner Freundin ins Kino, weil ein guter Film läuft.
words.example_translation: Today I go to the cinema with my girlfriend because a good movie is playing.
words.rule: Combine time, manner, place with conjunctions for natural speech
words.notes: This combines multiple grammar concepts

words.example: ..., aber ich denke, dass... / ..., und weil..., ...
words.example_translation: but I think that... / and because...
words.rule: These combinations appear frequently in conversation
words.pattern: Learn common conjunction combinations as units
words.notes: Helps with fluency and natural speech patterns
